title: 106_hr2531
content: The "Nuclear Regulatory Commission Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2000" authorizes appropriations of $465,400,000 for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and $6,000,000 for the Office of Inspector General for fiscal year 2000. SEC. 102. ALLOCATION OF AMOUNTS AUTHORIZED. The amounts authorized for fiscal year 2000 under section 101(a) are allocated as follows: $210,043,000 for Nuclear Reactor Safety, $63,881,000 for Nuclear Materials Safety, $42,143,000 for Nuclear Waste Safety, $4,840,000 for International Nuclear Safety Support, and $144,493,000 for Management and Support. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission can use up to 1% of these amounts for grants and cooperative agreements under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission can make grants and agreements with organizations like universities, State and local governments, and not-for-profit institutions. Grants must comply with relevant laws. Reallocation of funds allocated for specific programs is allowed, with limitations on the amount that can be reallocated. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission can reallocate funds allocated for specific programs, with limitations on the amount that can be reallocated. The reallocation must be notified in advance to specific committees and funds from the Nuclear Waste Fund can only be used for high-level nuclear waste activities. SEC. 103. LIMITATION. No payments under this Act can be made without prior approval in appropriation Acts. SEC. 104. NRC USER FEES. Amendment to the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 regarding NRC user fees. SEC. 105. COST RECOVERY. Cost recovery from government agencies. SEC. 105. Cost recovery from government agencies amended under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 to prescribe and collect fees from any Government agency starting October 1, 2000. Section 161k of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to allow members, officers, and employees of the Commission to carry firearms in the discharge of their official duties for common defense and security purposes. This authorization extends to employees of contractors and subcontractors engaged in property protection at U.S. facilities, as well as employees of licensed persons. Employees of persons licensed or certified by the Commission, including contractors, can carry firearms while protecting designated facilities or property important for defense and security. They can also make arrests without a warrant in connection with their official duties. Employees of contractors or Commission licensees can carry firearms and make arrests without a warrant for offenses committed in their presence or felonies under US laws if they have reasonable grounds to believe the individual has committed or is committing the felony. Arrests can only be made when the individual is within the area of the offense. This authority is limited to enforcing laws regarding US property custody. The arrest authority granted to employees of contractors or Commission licensees allows them to carry firearms, make arrests without a warrant for offenses committed in their presence or felonies under US laws if they have reasonable grounds to believe the individual has committed or is committing the felony. This authority is limited to enforcing laws regarding US property custody. The Secretary and the Commission, with the approval of the Attorney General, will issue guidelines to implement this subsection. SEC. 202 amends the Atomic Energy Act to include licensing authority or certification by the Commission. SEC. 203 addresses sabotage of nuclear facilities or fuel. Section 236a of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include penalties for intentionally causing damage to licensed nuclear facilities or materials. Penalties for intentionally causing damage to licensed nuclear facilities or materials include a fine of up to $10,000 or imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. SEC. 204 amends the Atomic Energy Act to limit the initial duration of a combined construction and operating license to 40 years. SEC. 205 removes the requirement for the Commission to maintain an office in the District of Columbia. SEC. 206 addresses Commission meetings. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission must conduct meetings according to regulations in effect on January 1, 1985. A complete transcript or recording is required for closed meetings. Definitions for "meeting" and "closed meeting" are provided. The term "closed meeting" is defined in section 9.101(d) of title 10 of the Code of Federal Regulations as of January 1, 1985.
